articles.headline: How Greece Could Escape the Euro
articles.snippet: What could be worse for Europe than a Greek default? Well, the country could revive the drachma.
articles.abstract: What could be worse for Europe than a Greek default? Well, the country could revive the drachma.
articles.lead_paragraph: Greece would be in much better shape now if it had never joined the euro zone, or if it had been kicked out in 2004 when it admitted that it had lied about its finances to join the club. So would the rest of Europe.

articles.headline: Detecting a Thaw in Myanmar, U.S. Aims to Encourage Change
articles.snippet: The thaw in relations with the United States follows a political transition in Myanmar that has raised the possibility that the new government will ease restrictions on basic freedoms.
articles.abstract: The thaw in relations with the United States follows a political transition in Myanmar that has raised the possibility that the new government will ease restrictions on basic freedoms.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States is considering a significant shift in its long-strained relationship with the autocratic government of Myanmar, including relaxing restrictions on financial assistance and taking other steps to encourage what senior American officials describe as startling political changes in the country.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: Some Unemployed Find Fault in Extension of Jobless Benefits
articles.snippet: As President Obama urges Congress to act on renewing an extension to unemployment benefits, some are arguing that it’s a hindrance to the economy and discourages workers.
articles.abstract: As President Obama urges Congress to act on renewing an extension to unemployment benefits, some are arguing that it’s a hindrance to the economy and discourages workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dan Tolleson, a researcher and writer with a Ph.D. in politics, has been out of work since 2009, except for brief stints as a driver. Still, he opposes President Obama’s call for Congress to renew extensions on unemployment benefits.

articles.headline: With Time Running Short, Jobs Managed His Farewells
articles.snippet: Steve Jobs spent his final weeks — as he had spent most of his life — in tight control of his choices.
articles.abstract: Steve Jobs spent his final weeks — as he had spent most of his life — in tight control of his choices.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the last few months, a steady stream of visitors to Palo Alto, Calif., called an old friend’s home number and asked if he was well enough to entertain visitors, perhaps for the last time.

articles.headline: Master of the Media Marketplace, and Its Demanding Gatekeeper
articles.snippet: As executives in music, film and publishing learned, a deal with Steve Jobs meant inclusion in one of the most important digital marketplaces on the planet. But the deals were made on Mr. Jobs’s terms.
articles.abstract: As executives in music, film and publishing learned, a deal with Steve Jobs meant inclusion in one of the most important digital marketplaces on the planet. But the deals were made on Mr. Jobs’s terms.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last November, Steven P. Jobs finally achieved his long-sought goal of bringing the Beatles to iTunes. But years before he made the deal, he began working on the promotional campaign for the music, personally designing advertisements that would sit in virtual mothballs as long as necessary.

articles.headline: Defending Life’s Work With Words of a Tyrant
articles.snippet: In Steve Jobs’s efforts to reshape the high-tech industry, he gained a reputation for making often cutting comments about competitors and to his own staff.
articles.abstract: In Steve Jobs’s efforts to reshape the high-tech industry, he gained a reputation for making often cutting comments about competitors and to his own staff.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The first time Steve Jobs ever bullied anyone was in the third grade. He and some pals “basically destroyed” the teacher, he once said.

articles.headline: Moving On, Minus Its Genius
articles.snippet: Apple could try to remake TV technology next as it embarks on its future without its resident genius, Steven P. Jobs, who died Wednesday.
articles.abstract: Apple could try to remake TV technology next as it embarks on its future without its resident genius, Steven P. Jobs, who died Wednesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Heard of Apple TV? A lot of people have not. That is because even though Steven P. Jobs helped upend so many businesses with a string of groundbreaking products in music, mobile phones, games and tablet computers, he barely made a dent in television.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: Adding Jobs, but Not Many, U.S. Economy Seems to Idle
articles.snippet: American employers added 103,000 jobs in September, the Labor Department said Friday, indicating that the economy is at least not weakening. The jobless rate held steady at 9.1 percent.
articles.abstract: American employers added 103,000 jobs in September, the Labor Department said Friday, indicating that the economy is at least not weakening. The jobless rate held steady at 9.1 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: American companies are adding jobs slowly and unevenly, just enough to plug the dike against a wave of fears that the economy could slip back into recession.

articles.headline: How Jobs Put Passion Into Products
articles.snippet: What Steve Jobs understood that others did not was that design works from the inside out — it’s the core of the product, not just its outer shell.
articles.abstract: What Steve Jobs understood that others did not was that design works from the inside out — it’s the core of the product, not just its outer shell.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the early 1990s Compaq Computer was the technology darling of the day, and PC sales were surging. Dell was promoting its build-on-demand model, Gateway computer shipped its products in boxes with Holstein cow markings, and I.B.M. had introduced the ThinkPad with its Little Tramp marketing campaign. Apple’s Macintosh was introduced during the 1984 Super Bowl but was considered a marginal outlier with its quirky proprietary operating system.

articles.headline: 10 Years Into Afghan War, a Thunderous Duel
articles.snippet: Coordinated strikes on outposts near the Pakistan border, timed apparently to mark the 10th anniversary of the start of the Afghan war, caused minimal damage, officers said.
articles.abstract: Coordinated strikes on outposts near the Pakistan border, timed apparently to mark the 10th anniversary of the start of the Afghan war, caused minimal damage, officers said.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORWARD OPERATING BASE TILLMAN, Afghanistan — The sun had been up less than a half-hour on the 10th anniversary of the start of the American-led war in Afghanistan when the first rocket struck. Flying in from near the border with Pakistan, it shook this outpost with an explosion that hinted at the long day ahead.
